title: Before 1 January 2022, will the Diem Association, co-founded by Facebook, launch a stablecoin?
preds: This is not likely to occur because there are only 10 days left in the year.
Novi, the wallet which Facebook is designing for use with Diem, has moved to a different stablecoin, the Pax Dollar: https://paxos.com/usdp/.
Passage of time, nothing on their website.
With recent regulatory focus on stablecoins, this is unlikely.

... Facebook and the Diem Association haven’t shelved plans to launch their own cryptocurrency at some point. “I do want to be clear that our support for Diem hasn’t changed and we intend to launch Novi with Diem once it receives regulatory approval and goes live. We care about interoperability and we want to do it right,” Novi project lead David Marcus said on Twitter.
https://techcrunch.com/2021/10/19/facebook-scales-back-its-crypto-ambitions-once-again/  [October 19, 2021] at some point :)
with SEC v. Ripple certainly not decided prior to Jan 14, I think rebranded facebook will wait for regulatory clarity before launching, so nope.

https://www.reuters.com/technology/stablecoins-face-same-safeguards-traditional-payments-2021-10-06/ I don't know what the current provisions are for this particular fake money, but when a change in the regulatory regime comes along or is suggested or clarified, the backers must do at least some redesign or tinkering or subornation.  This will take time and probably push this particular Facebook horror into next year. Full disclosure:  My grip on this topic is even more tenuous than my grip on most things, so perhaps best to ignore me.  For tips on how to do this, consult my daughter (or, come to think of it, my dog).
I had previously gone up on account of very optimistic statements made by the product lead, but in hindsight I moved too much

Based on this report that Diem says rollout is later this year or 2022. I still do not believe 2021 but i'll think more about it.

There are still some issues to overcome, therefore as some big projects it will take longer than expected.

A post by the leader of Diem/Novi: https://medium.com/@davidmarcus/good-stablecoins-a-protocol-for-money-and-digital-wallets-the-formula-to-fix-our-broken-payment-f11f59fc92d7 Unclear how to interpret.

https://github.com/diem/diem
Similar number of open issues, but the first has much cleaner commits (deprecate this feature, add this flag, update this dependency, fix typo), vs much scarier stuff on the Diem end.
I don't want to go to 15%... but I kind of want to go to 15%.
A more aggressive passage of time per my comment under Loki's forecast.

@yagudin asked me why I'm so low: Points driving me lower:
1. Base-rate. This has been going on since ~2017 or so.
2. Tech stack is immature. Mostly this is just looking into their github; https://github.com/diem/diem
- Log to find hung tests (starts logging after a minute). https://github.com/diem/diem/commit/43d44d975fd23c99994fa8e42f45344caf6940db
- Only stop at blocking errors - Used the new severity system to stop only at blocking errors. https://github.com/diem/diem/commit/05f533ee89d07dbcff5ba0bd4d44dd28d576ba5f
3. Facebook seemingly moving on, with "Facebook pay", which seems something totally different. https://cryptonews.com/news/facebook-to-ramp-up-payments-ahead-of-diem-launch-11097.htm
4. Inactivity in social media accounts:
https://www.diem.com/en-us/media-press-news
https://twitter.com/DiemDevelopers
https://twitter.com/diemassociation
https://developers.diem.com/main/changelog
https://github.com/diem/diem
5. The US regulatory climate doesn't feel particularly welcome at the moment Points driving me higher:
a. It's hard to judge technology readiness 5 months away, and Diem does probably have *something*
b. They have at several points announced that they will launch this year.
c. The fixed costs are probably fairly large, driving FB to launch Diem *eventually*
d. There is already an open source project building on top of Diem/aiming to bridge Diem with normal crypto, the Pontem network: https://twitter.com/pontemnetwork?lang=en. They seem to be fairly active
e. Novi, a wallet for Diem, already exists. https://www.novi.com/news.  So my overall impression is that, sure, I could be reading the tea leaves wrongly, but most of the time in situations like this I'd expect there to be a delay. More generally, by looking at their Github I get the strong hunch that this will not launch in the ~next month, but I'm much less sure whether they will be ready by Christmas, *and I expect Diem developers to be in the same position*, hence the 2021 announcement.

Paper by someone associated with Diem: https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3893937. Unclear how this updates, but -1% because if they're writting papers they're probably not doing technical work.
Coming closer to the crowd and also lowering over time

SEC fighting with XRP will yield some regulatory clarity at the earliest by the end of 2021 (if all deadlines are kept and no extensions granted), more likely 2022Q1, therefore I think the launch will not happen in this question's timeframe
Sniff the air, do I smell a regulatory storm headed this way? What do you do in a storm, start a controversial new initiative?
No. Facebook does not want to rock the regulatory boat.

To just build 'a' stable coin, I think they will not rush.
But if they saw (and created) the following opportunity: If a run on Tether proofed it to not be backed, this could cause widespread crypto-FUD. In that scenario, FB might want to step in and offer their stable-coin as on ramp for retail investors worldwide into BTC, essentially to take the place of USDT. Could they make it work? P=0.35
Will they make that strategic from guiding peoples attention to guiding peoples finances? P=0.15
Will they make it (build a stable coin) work? P=0.02

Looking at a medium term hold at just on the other side of a 50-50 thanks to one speculative comment in one article, quoting an insider stating it will "probably (launch) in the next 6 months" (1) More digging required and to come. 1.https://www.fool.com.au/2021/06/18/is-facebook-about-to-finally-launch-its-cryptocurrency/

https://www.novi.com/
I think this is going to be close.

I'm still projecting a launch this year, even with the move away from Switzerland.  I'm forecasting that it's going to come down to the volatility of the other cryptocurrencies.  People will want something more stable than Bitcoin and Doggecoin.

Swiss is out. Diem moving back to US to launch dollar backed stable coin this year.  Definetly can be done, but i am sort of wondering why Facebook would want to keep pursuing this? Of coirse maybe Facebook wants to do a lilot then exit the project. Any way i am gojng with an unsure 33%.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/12/facebook-backed-diem-is-moving-from-switzerland-to-the-us.html
A digital currency depends on trust and permission to exchange. Facebook lacks trust from most governments and increasingly citizens and companies

"While much attention has focused on Bitcoin in recent months, the ongoing experiments, pilots, and policy work around CBDCs could be equally if not more significant for the world of money. Central banks around the globe are warming up to CBDCs, triggered by Big Tech, and their ambitions to build alternative payment rails to existing card and bank-based payment systems with tokenized money, as in the case of the Facebook-backed Diem project.
[...]
Diem, the protocol layer, could receive FINMA regulatory approval before the end of 2021, and with it could launch a Diem Dollar, albeit many jurisdictions have publicly noted their antipathy towards the whole project previously."
https://ir.citi.com/6kaLOQ3DM84cUKeGSN0Vh2aTe7bi%2F%2BYrozLZ%2FuyAz5OHKIII0RFdq2LkPxTRKvFdnKelEwDGV9c%3D https://www.pymnts.com/cryptocurrency/2021/citi-report-cbdcs-will-be-part-of-digital-money-2-0/
Coin toss, maybe it is just a digital token.

This is a super comprehensive editorial on Diem updates within the last week. Big take away: to assuage regulatory worries over a stable coin, Diem is considering pegging to more than one currency. Does that change the definition of a “single currency” stable coin, as per the question?
https://www.thebanker.com/Editor-s-Blog/Facebook-s-Diem-joins-the-regulatory-fold

The Fed chair also expressed some concerns about so-called “stablecoins”, which are digital currencies that are pegged to the value of government-backed currencies such as the dollar or euro. Facebook’s Libra, which it now calls Diem, is an example of a stablecoin.
“The potentially fast and wide adoption of a global stablecoin, potentially a global currency governed only by the incentives of a private company, is something that will deserve and will receive the highest level of regulatory expectations,” Powell said. “Private stablecoins are not going to be an appropriate substitute for a sound monetary system based in central bank money.”
https://www.aljazeera.com/economy/2021/3/22/highly-volatile-powells-not-so-cryptic-warning-of-crypto
https://www.coindesk.com/thailand-central-bank-terra-stablecoin-tht Dialling back, going back to my initial view. Central banks globally are looking at Stablecoins as a threat to their control over monetary policy. Any launch without taking them into confidence may result in its use being declared illegal.

Currently conflicting data coming out in the last week about banks in Switzerland approving Diem for use.  The licensing process is "on-going", but no other confirmation.  While Q1 seems out of the question now, there is still plenty of time before 1 Jan to get approved (even outside the U.S.).  One interesting point not much talked about here is the current race to get several currencies out, like the digital Yuan.  You would think the U.S. would find a way to smooth over regulation in order to beat China to a worldwide-used digital currency (though some people think it should be a federal project and not Facebook, leading the charge).
https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-digital-currency-to-finally-launch-q1-2021-2
https://cointelegraph.com/news/many-pieces-of-the-diem-puzzle-still-missing-as-launch-gets-delayed
https://www.coindesk.com/sen-sherrod-brown-says-us-should-lead-the-way-on-cbdcs
Reversing based on @Fueled_by_Gummybears comment, but hesitant to go all in.

Increasing my probability for a Yes here  There still seems to be some ambiguity though and an imminent launch seems unlikely -
https://www.google.com/amp/s/cointelegraph.com/news/many-pieces-of-the-diem-puzzle-still-missing-as-launch-gets-delayed/amp The key issue as I see it is - Diem probably wants to launch quickly, given rumours of other tech companies having plans of their own
https://financefeeds.com/is-amazon-about-to-announce-a-proprietary-cryptocurrency-project/ However a quick launch may mean the platform will have a small userbase as traditional firms may still not be onboarded. Also there is quite a strong aversion in the EU to stablecoins
https://beincrypto.com/ecb-seeks-veto-power-over-emerging-stablecoins-in-europe/ Also with the stable act being proposed (not passed yet), still slightly puzzled by the urgency to launch quickly, with a good possibility of it being shut down in the future if the government decides to come up with more regulation
https://www.investopedia.com/new-stablecoin-bill-raises-hackles-of-crypto-community-5090337

Sticking to my current forecasts, as the possible market shrinks due to regulation.

Updating because of the info provided by @Fueled_by_Gummybears

This question specifies "Launch" but doesn't say it needs to be widely used, not in the U.S.  Diem is prepped to launch with a new blockchain, and Israeli company First is ready to get the currency to users and merchants "later this year". 
https://www.coindesk.com/diem-stablecoin-prepares-for-liftoff-with-fireblocks-custody-partnership
https://www.theblockcrypto.com/post/95008/diem-merchants-solution-stablecoin-first-fireblocks

A worldwide launch for use in payments in the brick-and-mortar economy will be difficult, as long as the Diem Association is domiciled in Zug, Switzerland ('Crypto Valley'), and e.g. the EU will demand a full compliance to regulatory frameworks of the single market. However, so far there are numerous "stablecoins", that mostly function as transfer vehicles for investments in crypto currency and tokens, and are proprietary netting currencies to crypto markets:
Tether (USDT)
USD Coin (USDC)
Dai (DAI)
cDai (CDAI)
Binance USD (BUSD)
cUSDC (CUSDC)
Paxos Standard (PAX)
HUSD (HUSD)
TerraUSD (UST)
TrueUSD (TUSD)
sUSD (SUSD)
Vai (VAI)
Aave USDC (AUSDC)
Neutrino USD (USDN) (selected by market cap > 100mn USD and rank among the top #200 of currencies, according to coingecko.com) Due to the increased interest of the public in the crypto currency market in general, and the large increase in valuations ("rally") in most currencies and tokens, a placement as planned in Q1 2021 as recently planned makes sense and would be well-received by market participants. facebook has a strong incentive to come up with the next growth story to boost earnings and investor confidence in its stock, and a placement under current market conditions would yield the highest return in money invested, which would mean solid cash reserve to the Diem foundation for future operations independent of cash infusions of its owners. It appears likely to me that Diem will launch first, without a specific use case, in order to create facts, and then settle regulatory issues under real-world data available later. EDIT:
"Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi said on CNBC Thursday the rideshare giant will consider accepting cryptocurrencies including bitcoin as a form of payment.
[...]
Uber has been a member of the libra (now diem) stablecoin association since October 2019."
https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/uber-ceo-says-company-to-consider-crypto-for-rides-not-its-balance-sheet-2021-02-11 https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/blockchain-bites%3A-mastercard-bny-mellon-embrace-crypto-amazon-floats-digital-currency "He also added that the organization is preparing to launch a single dollar-backed digital currency called the Diem Dollar. However, the launch day is yet unknown. The Diem Association is still waiting for the Swiss regulator FINMA’s approval to go ahead.
[...]
The fundamental change to lessen regulatory objections  BeInCrypto contacted Michael Gebert, the Chairman of the European Blockchain Association, for some predictions about the future of Diem. He is confident that neutralizing main objections to Libra’s original pitch by 'hiring spree of ex-political and tech veterans' will 'reinforce the project with new power.' "
https://beincrypto.com/libra-diem-is-getting-back-on-track-for-2021/ "He [Stuart Levey, CEO of the Geneva-based Diem Association] declined to comment on timing for the launch, which the Financial Times reported last week could be as early as January, saying only that it would only go ahead after approval by the Swiss markets watchdog."
https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN28B57D

Holding at 85%. The article (link below) says Diem is integrating with merchants, as opposed to direct users, which clears a huge hurdle in terms of regulation--they just need to find merchants that will accept their currency.  The biggest step will continue to be distancing Diem from Facebook, and making sure the entities remain separated.  As larger companies like Visa start looking at stablecoin as viable options for payment, this will become the norm.  
"Circle, for example, has invested in expanding its stablecoin following an OCC ruling that allows banks to process stablecoin payments. And during Visa's most recent earnings call, CEO Alfred Kelly said the card network is actively seeking cryptocurrency partners and said stablecoins were no different than any other method of payment." https://www.paymentssource.com/news/facebooks-diem-project-lays-groundwork-for-merchant-acceptance

Hattip @DNK89 for relevant reference to banks and stable coins. Lots of infrastructure to build and regulators to please, but it's a horse race to see who can provide what first.

Crypto assets are being accepted by regulations, then barriers are being superseded to allow a stablecoin as planned.

I think this is an interesting take by the South China Morning Post: it's not about the US president, but about SEC leadership.  Their overall analysis is that as BitCoin and others become more mainstream, the SEC will change it's tone, opening the door for more like Diem. No concrete date, and I agree with the assessment about getting regulators in the US on board before launch.
https://www.bitrates.com/news/p/facebooks-diem-will-the-global-cryptocurrency-go-live-in-2021

Based on no news what so ever, a wet finger in the wind says that the climate is not right to do this at this time. 
It is a great idea, but there are many hurdles especially for FB who is already fighting a pack of Congressional wolves who smell blood.
With size comes scrutiny and with no other successful model to refer to, it's pioneering work.

Facebook's intentions of launching a stablecoin are known. However they seem to be in no rush and don't seem to want to ignore regulatory issues. There is a good chance that 2021 will be a tough (regulatory speaking) year for other stablecoin (Tether for instance) and it sould take some time (>1 year) before the dust completely settle. I think this is when Facebook will launch his own stablecoin. With even odds I'd bet that Facebook won't launch a stablecoin in 2021 (not even speaking about the fact that Diem Association might disappear)
there's money to be made - opportunities are realized

"Facebook chief executive Mark Zuckerberg told lawmakers in a private meeting this week that his company’s controversial digital currency would not be launched anywhere in the world until it receives the backing of regulators in the United States." https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/09/19/facebooks-mark-zuckerberg-dined-with-lawmakers-last-night-privacy-cryptocurrency-were-menu/

- FINMA has guidelines for stablecoins, so the regulatory challenge for a geographically limited launch seems tractable within 1 year
- Launching a single currency stablecoin with a single product integration seems achievable in a year
On a limited trial basis.  There are extremely high financial considerations let alone the laws regulating money laundering.

This is the hardest question I've faced since there is no precedent and creating currencies is normally the function and right of a sovereign nation. Creating a currency is something that Ripple is currently under investigation by the SEC for creating and offering XRP to investors as a way to to settle claims. The goal of the stablecoin is to span the globe thus stepping on the toes of multiple governments simultaneously. This is like painting a target on your back at a shooting range.

If Diem can drop the association with Facebook’s social media side, this will happen in the next year. Congress (and thus investors) are too squeamish about size and influence of Mark Zuckerburg’s company to approve this while they are still connected (I see it as similar to how Google got too big for its britches and is now rebranded as Alphabet). One thing that is going to be a big player is how fast China continues to roll out its cryptocurrency. Diem would be a smart way to pushback, challenge and compete with other cryptocurrencies currently being floated on the market, but not yet fully released.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-06-01/china-is-making-cryptocurrency-to-challenge-bitcoin-and-dollar
FB will continue to expand its reach as much as possible as it positions itself to fight the government on antitrust related issues and actions.

Everything associate to Facebook doesn't seem to be in a good vibe for the next US presidency.
How can we think to dismantle a company and on the other hand to make legislation making able a new business line for this same company?
https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/26/anti-facebook-agitators-biden-era-450347 How Diem Association will be able to distance itself from Facebook faith?

It seems likely to launch, but will anyone want to use it?
They can certainly launch it. Whether it will be successful I don't know.
The Financial Times reported that Diem could go live in a limited way

The new Stable  Act if passed in the current form sets some pretty high bars for one a banking license would be required and also mentions fed reserve and FDIC approval 6 months before issuance. Also as the name indicates stablecoins need to be pegged to the dollar which means having mechanism for backing their value with a basket of very liquid short term assets which need to hold incase there is a run on the stablecoin at any time. (Ie a huge sell order should not trigger change the dollar peg rate).
While the crypto community is up in arms, and we would have to look at the final act that gets passed (if it does get any traction at all since the current congress is set to expire).
It would be a fair assumption to make that for this to get a regulatory blessing it would have to go through a rigorous checking process. 
Moreover FB has very little credibility with the government. While I do think Stablecoins have a lot of merit and will be adopted eventually but the probability of that happening in the next one year seems a bit unlikely considering the regulatory hurdles it may face
https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.forbes.com/sites/seansteinsmith/2020/12/09/cryptocurrency-legislation-is-on-the-rise--what-the-proposed-stable-act-could-mean-for-crypto/amp/ https://www.investopedia.com/new-stablecoin-bill-raises-hackles-of-crypto-community-5090337

First floating the idea last year Facebook & Partners were met with quite a lot of resistance from regulators around the world. After a rebrand the Association has since made various tweaks and applied for a payment system licence from Swiss regulators, in April 2020. Diem said that it would proceed “only upon receiving regulatory approval, including a payment systems license for the operational subsidiary of the Association from FINMA”. The Financial Times recently reported that Diem could go live in a limited capacity as early as January.  I believe there is a good chance Diem will be launched in SOME form sooner than later.

now only Diem instead of Libra, I expect that change to be due to inofficial heads up of actual defi by FB not being tolerated - yet (=next 1-3 years). Since stablecoin feasible for FB: 100%, but maybe in Q1/Q2 of 2022. So for end of 2021: 90%.

I think that Finma will allow Libra/Diem to trade and that Stablecoin will be a reality.   That is why I am putting the likelihood as 75% for my first guess.    What I don't know is how long it usually tales for Finma to make a decision.     I think that Diem will be ready to launch as soon as it is allowed to and that the decision should take less than 1 year.    LoL I need to investigate how long Finma takes to reach a decision and I know that they are working in collaboration with other international financial institutions so that may take more time than a year.    I should probably have started at 50/50 but I cant help thinking that if something is inevitable then why wait so long to legislate?
Seems like this will be a given in a year.
Another way of corporatised government. So let's do it!

They will push it through with the new US govt.
1 year is a long enough time for them to do it.

Facebook is fairly reviled by regulators and legislators, who recognize the threat a Facebook stablecoin would be to their national sovereignty, especially given Facebook's track record of privacy violations and sketchy data practices.  At the same time, a USD-based stablecoin rolled out around the world to Facebook's users could be a way to bolster dollar hegemony, which is obviously desired by the US Government. Starting my forecast at 50% and will adjust as time goes on.
Crypto currencies are THE alt-asset for 2021. By the end of 2021 a major central bank will establish a crypto-conversion platform and bring some structure to what is now an unorganised asset class.
